DataElement.preferredDefinition: A disturbance in the prooxidant-antioxidant balance in favor of the former, leading to potential damage. Indicators of oxidative stress include damaged DNA bases, protein oxidation products, and lipid peroxidation products.  The damage to biological tissues is caused by superoxide and other free radicals generated by many factors, including exposure to alcohol, medications, trauma, cold, toxins, and radiation or by antimicrobial cellular immunity, metabolic abnormality, or "normal" aging; not synonymous with hypoxia or hyperoxia.  Oxidative stress promotes a range of degenerative disorders, including cancer, diabetes, premature aging, Alzheimer's, and many others._The determination of the amount of a particular constituent of a mixture or of the biological or pharmacological potency of a drug.:Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities._The list of values for oxidative stress assay types.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: The list of values for oxidative stress assay types.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A tripeptide comprised of three amino acids (cysteine, glutamic acid, and glycine) present in most mammalian tissue. Glutathione acts as an antioxidant, a free radical scavenger and as a detoxifying agent. Glutathione is also important as a cofactor for the enzyme glutathione peroxidase, in the uptake of amino acids and participates in leukotriene synthesis. Under the influence of glutathione S-transferase, glutathione can react with a number of harmful products, such as halides, epoxides and free radicals, to form harmless inactive products. In erythrocytes, these reactions prevent oxidative damage by reduction of methemoglobin and peroxides. Glutathione is also involved in the formation and maintenance of disulfide bonds in proteins and in transport of amino acids across cell membranes.:The regulation of a particular factor which attempts to keep that factor at an equilibrium or norm. This involves a feedback mechanism that recognizes any deviance from the norm and initiates counter-measures to return the factor back to its desired level. An example of homeostasis is temperature regulation. (Biology Online Dictionary)

Concepts.definition: A tripeptide comprised of three amino acids (cysteine, glutamic acid, and glycine) present in most mammalian tissue. Glutathione acts as an antioxidant, a free radical scavenger and a detoxifying agent. Glutathione is also important as a cofactor for the enzyme glutathione peroxidase, in the uptake of amino acids, and in the synthesis of leukotrienes. As a substrate for glutathione S-transferase, this agent reacts with a number of harmful chemical species, such as halides, epoxides and free radicals, to form harmless inactive products. In erythrocytes, these reactions prevent oxidative damage through the reduction of methemoglobin and peroxides. Glutathione is also involved in the formation and maintenance of disulfide bonds in proteins and in the transport of amino acids across cell membranes.
The body's maintenance of a consistent internal environment within a narrow range of variation. It is important to the continuation of life.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The degradation of lipids caused by an oxidative attack from free radicals.

Concepts.definition: The degradation of lipids caused by an oxidative attack from free radicals.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An oxygen species that carries an unpaired electron (e.g., the hydroxyl radical and the superoxide anion). These radicals are very powerful oxidizing agents and cause structural damage to proteins and nucleic acids. They mediate the damaging effects of ionizing radiation. (from Online Medical Dictionary):The act of bringing into being.

Concepts.definition: Organic or inorganic chemicals that contain an oxygen atom with an unpaired electron. This unstable electron configuration causes these chemicals to be highly reactive with other molecules.
The act of bringing into being.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: An action taken in pursuit of an objective; the state of being active.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

Concepts.definition: Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.
